LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
   
Classification  Poverty classification: Targeted intervention 
Sector: Agriculture and natural resources 
Subsectors: Irrigation and drainage, water resource management 
Themes:  Pro-poor  growth,  environmental  sustainability,  and 
governance 
Subthemes:  Fostering  physical  infrastructure  development, 
developing  rural  areas,  civil  society  participation,  human 
development, and natural resource conservation 
   
Environment  Category: B 
Assessment  An initial environmental examination was undertaken. 
   
Project Description  The provinces of Binh Dinh, Quang Binh, Quang Ngai, Quang Tri, 
Thanh Hoa, and Thua Thien Hue in central Viet Nam have high 
rural poverty and suffer disproportionately from natural disasters 
that cause  loss of life  and damage to houses and  crops. Six 
irrigation subprojects (one in each province) with good potential 
for increased agricultural production were selected according to 
agreed selection criteria: (i) financially and economically viable, (ii) 
contributing  strongly  to  poverty  reduction,  (iii)  environmentally 
sustainable,  (iv)  compliant  with  principles  of  integrated  water 
resource management, and (v) responsive to natural disaster risk 
reduction initiatives. 
 
In these schemes, the Project will (i) improve irrigation system 
management by reforming service providers and concomitantly 
building  capacity  of  client  water  users  as  partners  in  scheme 
operation  and  maintenance,  and  (ii)  improve  irrigation  and 
drainage  infrastructure  and  strengthen  natural  disaster  risk 
reduction measures. Physical works will include rehabilitation and 
new construction of water conservation, irrigation, drainage, and 
protective measures.  
   
Rationale  Continued,  deep,  and  lasting  poverty  reduction  in  the  central 
coastal region depends on improving returns from agriculture, a 
sector  whose  performance  is  held  back  by  physical  and 
institutional  constraints.  The  Project  is  premised  on  the 
assumption that improved performance of the region’s irrigation 
schemes depends on introducing service-oriented management 
systems  that  are  cost-efficient,  effective,  autonomous,  and 
accountable.  The  participation  of  water  user  groups  in  the 
planning, design, implementation, and operation and maintenance 
of subprojects is not only indispensable for sustainable operation, 
but also a cost-efficient means of helping service providers meet 
their goals.

ii 
Impact and Outcome  The  project  impact  will  be  reduced  poverty  in  six  central 
provinces.  The  project  outcome  will  be  increased  agricultural 
production in selected irrigation subprojects.  
   
Cost Estimates  The total project cost, including contingencies, taxes, and duties, 
is  estimated  at  $99.0  million.  The  foreign  exchange  cost  is 
estimated at $37.8 million or 38% of the total project cost. The 
local currency cost including taxes is $61.2 million or 62% of the 
total project cost. 
   
Financing Plan  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a loan of $74.3 
million equivalent from its Special Fund resources to finance 75% 
of the project cost amounting to $99.0 million. The Government 
will finance about $24.7 million or 25% of the project cost.  
   
Loan Amount and Terms  ADB will provide a loan of various currencies equivalent to $74.3 
million from its Special Funds resources. The loan will have a term 
of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years, with an interest 
charge of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum thereafter. 
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June 2012 
   
Estimated Project  31 December 2011 
Completion Date 
   
Executing Agency  The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) 
   
Implementation  The Project will be executed by MARD through its Central Project 
Arrangements  Office (CPO) based in Hanoi. CPO will set up a central project 
management  unit  (CPMU)  to  (i)  provide  overall  project 
management  and  coordination,  (ii)  liaise  with  the  provincial 
people's committee and provincial department of agriculture and 
rural development (DARD) in each province to improve irrigation 
management systems, (iii) guide and coordinate DARD in each 
province  to  improve  irrigation  infrastructure,  (iv)  implement  the 
project  performance  management  system  (PPMS),  (v)  procure 
consulting  services,  (vi)  coordinate  with  the  provincial  project 
management units (PPMUs) in each province to procure goods 
and  services  through  international  competitive  bidding,  (vii) 
prepare  forecasts  of  contract  awards  and  disbursements  and 
arrange  project  account  audits,  (viii)  prepare  major  reports 
covering the whole Project by consolidating the reports from each 
province, and (viii) prepare the project completion report. 
 
  In each target province, a PPMU will be created under the direct 
administration of DARD. Each PPMU will be headed by a full-time 
subproject manager with qualifications acceptable to ADB. The 
PPMU  will  improve  irrigation  management  systems  (output  1), 
improve  irrigation  infrastructure  (output  2),  procure  goods  and 
services using local competitive bidding, operationalize the PPMS,

iii 
and  implement  resettlement,  environmental  management,  a 
gender action plan, an HIV/AIDS awareness program, and (in Tra 
Cau subproject) an ethnic minority development plan.  
 
  The vice minister of MARD will head a project steering committee 
set up to provide policy and strategy advice and to communicate 
project outcomes with other ministries. 
   
Procurement  Civil  works,  goods,  and  related  services  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. Civil works 
contracts estimated to cost more than $2 million equivalent will be 
procured  through  international  competitive  bidding  among 
prequalified firms with proven technical competence acceptable to 
ADB. Civil works contracts estimated to cost $2 million or less will 
be procured through local competitive bidding procedures. State-
owned enterprises will be eligible to bid for contracts if they are 
financially autonomous, independently managed, and operate on 
the basis of commercial practice. Equipment to be procured under 
the Project includes vehicles, motorcycles, computers, software, 
and water quality monitoring equipment. Such equipment will be 
procured by international competitive bidding where the cost is 
more than $1 million, international shopping where the cost is 
$500,000 to $1 million per package, and local competitive bidding 
where the cost is less than $500,000. Where local suppliers are 
few,  procurement  may  be  made  by  direct  purchase,  with  a 
threshold of $100,000, as will be the case for negotiated service 
contracts with nongovernment organizations (NGOs). 
   
Consulting Services  The Project will require 227 person-months of domestic and 103 
person-months  of  international  consultants.  All  consultants, 
NGOs,  and  local  institutions  will  be  selected  and  engaged  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  selection  and 
engagement of domestic consultants. The quality- and cost-based 
selection  method  will  be  used.  The  consultants  will  build  the 
capacity  of  MARD  and  DARD  to  develop  and  operationalize 
business  plans  for  irrigation  management  companies  and 
enterprises, create and operationalize PPMS, and coordinate and 
supervise project implementation. Local consulting firms, NGOs, 
and institutions will be engaged to provide training, implement the 
gender  action  plan  and  HIV/AIDS  awareness  program,  create 
water user groups and associations, complete the final design of 
works and supervise their construction, and monitor performance. 
A team of international and domestic consultants, some of whom 
will be based in Thua Thien Hue, will assist CPMU in MARD and 
the PPMU in each of the project provinces.  
 
Project Benefits and  The Project will establish a service-oriented approach to irrigation 
Beneficiaries  water  management  where  provincial  agencies  and  the  water 
users will be empowered to jointly manage irrigation schemes. 
This will be done by (i) restructuring the water service providers as

iv 
financially  autonomous  entities,  and  forming  water  users  into 
groups  to  participate  fully  in  irrigation  management;  and  (ii) 
constructing and rehabilitating water management infrastructure in 
each subproject area. Natural disaster risk reduction measures 
will complement the physical improvements. The main quantifiable 
benefits  for  the  subproject  areas  are  incremental  outputs  of 
agricultural products from 57,755 hectares deriving from (i) higher 
cropping  intensities,  (ii)  higher  yields  due  to  reliable  and  full 
irrigation water supply, and (iii) incremental output from shrimp 
and fish farming. 
 
About 400,500 people in the six subproject areas will benefit from 
increased agricultural income and more jobs. Many of them will 
benefit from improved water supply for domestic use and reduced 
vulnerability  to  natural  disasters.  About  38%  of  beneficiary 
households live below the poverty line of $0.33 per person per 
day. Generally, farm benefits are expected to nearly double, lifting 
about 6,000 households above the poverty line. About 25% of the 
households are headed by women and have limited access to 
adult  labor,  land,  and  credit.  A  gender  action  plan  will  be 
implemented to assist these households. Resettlement plans will 
ensure  that  project-affected  people  will  be  adequately 
compensated in accordance with ADB guidelines. The Project is 
economically viable, with an economic internal rate of return of 
15% for the base case. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The main risks arise from delays in realizing benefits. Possible 
causes  of  delay  are  slowness  in  recruiting  consultants  and 
appointing  central  and  provincial  project  management  staff, 
resistance  of  vested  interests  to  changes  in  organizational 
structure  of  service  providers,  cumbersome  administrative 
processes related to contract awards, and insensitive handling of 
resettlement. Resettlement and compensation of people affected 
by the construction works need to be completed before civil works 
contracts are awarded.  
 
The Project includes measures to mitigate the above risks, and all 
environmental,  social,  and  financial  risks.  The  principal 
assumption  is  that  the  Government  will  fully  support  the 
institutional reform process, including the restructuring of service 
providers and promotion of more autonomous water user groups. 
Project consultants will help the provincial authorities complete 
resettlement  on  time.  MARD  has  experience  in,  and  a  good 
understanding  of  Government  and  ADB  requirements  for 
resettlement.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Central Region Water Resources Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Rural Poverty and Agriculture 
2.  Viet Nam’s energetic pursuit of development over the last two decades, accompanied by 
economic liberalization and greater openness to the outside world, has produced a remarkable 
transformation in what was hitherto a traditional and poor rural society. Strong economic growth 
has led to increasingly rapid urbanization and correspondingly unprecedented increases in 
wages and quality of life. Despite the changes this has wrought and the pressures placed on the 
country’s decrepit infrastructure, Viet Nam has retained its rich culture and a rural landscape of 
unparalleled beauty. The country’s agricultural land, predominantly devoted to rice cultivation, 
includes the Red River and Mekong River delta areas as well as the narrow plains stretching 
along the 1,500 kilometers (km) of coastline connecting these mighty river deltas. 
 
3.  The rural tranquility conceals a deepening crisis. Although Viet Nam’s economic growth 
has averaged more than 7% over the last 5 years and overall poverty has been reduced from 
58.1% in 1993 to 24.1% in 2004,1 poverty reduction has not been uniform and pockets of 
extreme  poverty  persist  in  rural  areas.2  Inequalities  in  income  distribution  have  increased, 
reflecting higher growth in per capita income in areas that are rapidly developing, and resource-
rich than in areas that are remote, lack infrastructure, have few resources, or are vulnerable to 
natural disasters. Rural areas have not benefited to the same extent from liberalization. Most 
institutions serving rural communities have changed little from an earlier era of central control, 
and  have  not  benefited  from  the  public  administration  reforms  that  have  brought  more 
immediate benefits to fast-developing urban areas. 
 
4.  Viet Nam’s population of 83 million is still predominantly rural (60 million or 73%) and 
dependent on agriculture for livelihoods and basic needs.3 The contribution from agriculture, 
forestry,  and  aquaculture  to  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  was  20.5%  in  2005  and, 
although the sector’s contribution is expected to decline to 15.5% by 2010, the sector led in job 
creation—adding 4.6 million out of 7.5 million new jobs—during 2001–2005. Over the next 5 
years, agriculture is expected to grow by about 3% (compared with 10% for industry and 
construction, and 8% for services). By 2010, the number of people engaged in agriculture is 
expected to decline to 44 million or 50% of the total population. 
 
5.  Viet Nam’s investments in agriculture, equivalent to about 5% of the national budget, are 
spent mostly on irrigation and forestry.4 For irrigation, the upgrading of existing infrastructure 
dominates the Government's program (64% of spending in 2003). Nevertheless, about 40% (or 
2.25 million hectares [ha]) of the commanded areas are not yet served. The financing needed to

2.  The Critical Role of Water 
6.  Viet Nam is exposed to typhoons that cause flash floods, landslides, and coastal erosion 
along its eastern seaboard. Its monsoon climate guarantees abundant water at some times of 
the year, leading to flooding of much of its most productive agricultural land, but also water 
shortages during the dry season. Rivers that originate within Viet Nam are short and steep, 
offering limited opportunities for multipurpose water storage reservoirs, and about 60% of its 
water resources originate from neighboring countries. The high regional, seasonal, and annual 
variability of water supply is likely to become more so because of climate change associated 
with global warming. The impacts of human activities on some river basin upper catchments 
aggravate the perceptibly increased flooding and sediment discharge during the wet season and 
diminished low flows during the dry season. Salt water intrusion is advancing into coastal plains 
and delta areas, limiting opportunities for extraction of water for agricultural, domestic, and 
industrial uses. This is exacerbated by increased upstream withdrawals to meet the growing 
needs of an industrializing and urbanizing economy. Pollution of surface and ground water is 
emerging as a problem in many river basins. 
 
7.  Viet  Nam  has  a  long  history  of  water  management  in  support  of  agricultural 
intensification and the development of a strong industrial sector.5 Its transformation  into a 
market-oriented economy has brought decentralization, socialization, grassroots democracy, 
and the promotion of small-scale private enterprise to the fore of its water sector reform agenda, 
creating a favorable environment for institutional change at all levels of water management.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Irrigation Performance in the Central Coastal Region 
8.  The  central  region  has  particularly  severe  constraints  that  single  it  out  for  special 
support.6 The Government's 5-year socioeconomic development plan (SEDP) for 2006–2010 
(footnote 1) notes the region’s persistent poverty which declined to an average of 38% during 
1992–2004 from 74.5% in the north and 47.2% in the south central coastal regions.7 The 
coastal plain, which encompasses the region’s irrigation schemes, experiences 4–6 typhoons 
each year on average.8 Completion or rehabilitation of these schemes (covering not only major 
structures for diversion and conveyance of water, but also lower level canals and drains and 
measures to protect against floods), is a prerequisite to full performance.

than 1% of total water resources used to meet municipal and industrial demands.

3
9.  The major constraints, however, relate to management (Appendix 1). The Ministry of 
Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) and other national agencies involved in managing 
and using water follow an engineering, sectoral approach to water resource development and 
have yet to fully assimilate integrated water resources management (IWRM) into their planning 
strategies and work practices. Provincial agencies have considerable authority to make key 
decisions on water infrastructure development and management, subject to conformity with 
national sector policies and strategies, but their capacity to target poverty in water projects and 
coordinate  various  cross-sectoral  aspects  of  resource  management  is  limited.  Irrigation 
management  companies  (IMCs)—state-owned  public  utility  enterprises  responsible  for  the 
operation and maintenance (O&M) of large irrigation schemes—display little service orientation 
or capacity to manage irrigation in a sustainable manner. Maintenance is frequently neglected in 
favor of Government-financed periodic rehabilitation. At the tertiary level, water users have yet 
to be fully empowered to take water management decisions affecting their livelihoods. Critically, 
there is a disconnect between the payment of water user fees and the delivery of water in the 
correct amounts and at the appropriate time. The institutional context and issues affecting 
irrigation performance are described in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  Government's Strategy 
10.  The SEDP defines development objectives for the coming 5 years. It incorporates the 
fundamentals of Viet Nam’s Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy9 and the 
poverty reduction partnership agreement with ADB. To achieve the SEDP’s aim of eliminating 
extreme poverty in rural areas, the Government will focus on poor regions and make better use 
of their development potential. In relation to agriculture, SEDP sets out several approaches to 
increase returns:  
 
  (i)  complete, rehabilitate, and modernize water infrastructure to ensure optimum use 
and conservation of water resources for irrigation, water supply, and industry; 
  (ii)  build the capacity of Government agencies at all levels to incorporate grassroots 
democracy in managing resources and delivering services; 
  (iii)  increase the role of users in O&M of irrigation systems; 
  (iv)  develop better natural disaster forecasting and warning capability; 
  (v)  become  more  responsive  to  the  requirements  of  international  markets  and 
increase  export  competitiveness  by  diversifying  and  giving  more  attention  to 
quality; 
  (vi)  create greater opportunity for private sector development and intensify linkages 
between industry and agriculture; 
  (vii)  provide credit and more innovative loans for the poor; and 
  (viii)  give priority in social support programs to ethnic minorities and others whose 
poverty is more deeply entrenched, including poor women and children. 
 
11.  In 2004, MARD launched a national program to rehabilitate irrigation schemes and 
establish a service-oriented approach where provincial agencies and the water users will be 
empowered to jointly manage irrigation schemes. In this way MARD aims to raise the efficiency 
of water delivery, realize the full potential of its investments, and reduce subsidies for O&M.

3.  Lessons Learned 
12.  ADB has supported water resource projects in Viet Nam from the early 1990s.11 Project 
completion reports prepared for two—the Irrigation and Flood Protection Rehabilitation Project12 
and the Red River Delta Water Resources Sector Project13—highlight the limited gains that can 
be achieved by physically improving irrigation schemes if commensurate attention is not given 
to the social, institutional, and regulatory frameworks within which they function. MARD, until 
recently, has shown little interest in participatory processes for planning, design, and O&M of 
completed schemes. Its contracting experience before 1993 was exclusively with state-owned 
enterprises (SOEs) for which fixed-cost norms (largely unrelated to market value) sidestepped 
true competition and worked against quality construction. MARD’s inexperience with ADB's 
safeguard policies and guidelines for procurement and selection of consultants led to inordinate 
delays that were exacerbated by the Government's own complex and time-consuming review 
and approval procedures.  
 
13.  Specific lessons related to project design are: (i) policy, regulatory, and institutional 
shortcomings—particularly  the  low  capacity  of  institutions  at  provincial  and  lower  levels  of 
government—need to be fully recognized and addressed in the design phase; (ii) the capacity of 
executing and implementing agencies to incorporate social, environmental, and governance 
aspects needs to be complemented by sustained technical assistance (TA); (iii) the number of 
subprojects should be kept to a minimum and they should be straightforward and simple to 
implement;14 (iv) irrigation water users should be engaged early in planning and design to 
ensure that their needs are adequately reflected and to include, under project financing, the 
small-scale works needed to ensure equitable distribution of water at field level; (v) specific 
actions targeting women and female-headed households ensure more equitable distribution of 
benefits in rural development projects;15 (vi) a whole river basin approach to the management of 
water resources should be taken in areas with potential water scarcity; and (vii) greater attention 
needs to be given to monitoring project performance, including establishing baseline conditions 
prior to project implementation.

14.  Analyses of ADB's projects in the sector have consistently shown that a broad, systems 
approach  is  needed  to  identify  constraints  and  the  means  of  overcoming  them.  Such  an 
approach draws development planners, implementers, operators, and users into a partnership 
for  improved  project  design  and  scheme  management.  In  disaster  prone  areas,  improved 
performance also depends on putting into place effective risk reduction measures. Achieving full 
potential  therefore  requires  practical  and  holistic  interventions  to  (i)  build  capacity  of  key 
stakeholder agencies at various levels, including introducing community-based, demand-driven 
approaches such as PIM; (ii) eliminate physical impediments to efficient scheme operation; and 
(iii) provide appropriate levels of support for project management. 
 
4.  ADB's Strategy for Water Sector Operations 
15.  When ADB resumed lending to Viet Nam in 1993, the country was the world’s third 
largest rice exporter. Nevertheless, the nation’s water resources infrastructure, on which rice 
production and the welfare of a large segment of society depended, had deteriorated to a poor 
condition. ADB supported the rehabilitation of large, functioning irrigation schemes to assure 
their continued operation, obtain rapid improvements in agricultural production and economic 
growth, and raise living conditions and quality of life.  
 
16.  More  recently,  ADB's  emphasis  in  rural  development  has  shifted  to  balancing 
infrastructure investments with livelihood support and capacity building, reflecting the adoption 
in 1999 of poverty reduction as ADB's overarching goal16 and the more general shift by the 
global development community in 2000 to the Millennium Development Goals as the benchmark 
for monitoring poverty reduction. In response, the CSP 2002–2004 allocated one third of lending 
to the impoverished central region. With the new emphasis on livelihood support and poverty 
targeting, project preparation became more participatory, but technical content became diluted 
and projects more complicated.17  
 
17.  ADB, in close partnership with other lending and funding agencies, seeks to maximize 
the economic growth and poverty reduction potential of water sector infrastructure investments 
by targeting poor regions, and incorporating institutional support and policy reforms in line with 
the water policy.18 Hence, greater emphasis is now being given to improving water service 
delivery, increasing the autonomy and accountability of service providers to meet the needs of 
the poor, and establishing sustainable O&M through appropriate levels of cost recovery and 
user participation. ADB is providing long-term capacity building for national, river basin, and 
provincial IWRM to support its investment program.19 Concurrently, the Second Red River Basin 
Sector Project is establishing IWRM in the Red River basin and building relevant institutional 
capacity  in  MARD  and  the  provincial  agencies.  In  accordance  with  ADB's  disaster  and 
emergency assistance policy,20 all new projects incorporate disaster risk reduction measures to 
prepare for and avoid the worst impacts of natural disasters.

18.  Many bilateral and multilateral funding agencies are active in the water sector (Appendix

6.  Project Rationale 
19.  There is compelling evidence that rejuvenation of rural economies through accelerated 
agricultural  and  rural  development  is  essential  to  an  inclusive  growth  strategy,  not  just  to 
increase agricultural production and rural incomes but also to buttress nonfarm and urban job 
creation and to reduce migration of underemployed rural workers to urban centers.21 Continued, 
deep, and lasting poverty reduction in the central coastal region depends on improving returns 
from  agriculture,  a  sector  whose  performance  is  held  back  by  physical  and  institutional 
constraints. Transforming irrigated agriculture requires interventions to improve the performance 
of subnational agencies, delegate greater responsibility to them for investment decisions, and 
introduce community-based, demand-driven approaches including PIM. 
 
20.  The  Project,  prepared  under  TA  4001-VIE,22  assumes  that  the  region’s  irrigation 
schemes can best be improved by introducing service-oriented management systems that are 
(i) financially sound (cost-efficient); (ii) capable of meeting agreed service targets (effective); (iii) 
enabled  and  structured  to  prepare  work  plans,  budgets,  user  fees,  and  staff  plans 
(autonomous); and (iv) responsive to the needs of the client base (accountable). To realize 
project objectives in a socially just manner, agencies involved in water resources management 
need to be attuned to the special needs of disadvantaged segments of the communities to 
ensure that the benefits of irrigation do not accrue only to the wealthier households, and that 
ethnic minorities and female-headed households can equitably benefit from the Project. The 
Project recognizes that the participation of water user groups (WUGs) in the planning, design, 
implementation, and O&M of subprojects is not only indispensable for sustainable operation, but 
is also a cost-efficient means of helping service providers meet their goals. Finally, the Project 
will ensure that the basic irrigation infrastructure functions correctly in accordance with modern 
technical standards. The Project reflects the poverty reduction targets in the SEDP and the 
Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy and responds to the Government’s 
policy  to  improve  irrigation  by  making  water  service  delivery  more  decentralized  and 
participatory. The concepts have been tested in pilot projects, and project design draws heavily 
on the recommendations23 for multi-stakeholder participation.24

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
21.  The Project’s impact will be reduced poverty in six central provinces (Appendix 3).25 The 
Project’s outcome will be increased agricultural production in selected irrigation subprojects.26 
About 400,500 people, 38% of whom live below the poverty line of $0.33 per person per day, 
will benefit directly from the Project.  
 
B.  Outputs 
22.  The Project’s outputs will be (i) cost-efficient, effective, accountable, and autonomous 
water service providers working in partnership with client water users to manage irrigation 
schemes;  and  (ii)  rehabilitated  and  completed  irrigation  and  drainage  infrastructure 
incorporating measures to reduce vulnerability to natural disasters within selected schemes.  
 
23.  In each target province, the provincial people's committee (PPC), DARD, and irrigation 
management companies (IMCs)27 are eager to modernize the management of their irrigation 
schemes and make water service delivery more decentralized and participatory. Subprojects 
were  selected  and  feasibility  studies  conducted  during  project  processing  with  the  close 
participation  of  stakeholders,  including  water  user  representatives.  Subprojects  and  their 
component works satisfy the following agreed criteria: (i) financially and economically viable, (ii) 
contributing strongly to poverty reduction, (iii) environmentally sustainable, (iv) compliant with 
principles  of  IWRM,  and  (v)  responsive  to  natural  disaster  risk  reduction  initiatives.  Their 
detailed design and construction will be implemented according to standards and procedures 
developed  jointly  with  the  provinces  during  project  preparation.  The  Project  has  two 
components:

b.  Strengthen Water User Participation 
27.  Working through MARD’s department of water resources (DWR),31 the Project will help 
establish WUGs on the basis of hydraulic boundaries, replacing (in most cases) the user groups

meet with some resistance. Hence, the development of a set of agreed principles that are 
endorsed by MARD, DARD, and the PPCs will be a prerequisite. National, provincial, and 
district  workshops  will  raise  awareness  of  PIM,32  develop  province-specific  guidelines  and

the new WUGs.

information software linked to a geographic information system (GIS), will be designed and put 
into operation in close consultation with the Central Project Office (CPO) and DARD. Initial 
conditions determined through baseline surveys in each subproject will be updated every 6

of  the  project  area,  female  farmers  encounter  many  impediments  to  their  participation  in 
economic activities and leadership roles. Nevertheless, women assume a disproportionately 
high share of the burden of farm labor and are poorer than men. A gender action plan (GAP) 
has been prepared for each subproject to ensure more equitable distribution of benefits and to 
improve the participation of female farmers in system O&M. The GAP will be underpinned by 
gender sensitization programs for staff of DARD and the IMCs. To magnify the impact of gender 
awareness and to reach the widest possible female target for leadership training, agricultural 
extension services, and building business management skills, the Project will train staff of the 
Vietnam Women’s Union (VWU) as trainers. The Project will thereafter support training led by 
trained VWU staff. The Project will also support HIV/AIDS-related awareness raising to counter 
the risk of HIV/AIDS among male and female migrant workers and to reduce risks of infection 
among local populations through in-migration of construction workers. The program will target 
high-risk population groups, including contractors, construction workers, and migrants.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Social Benefits and Impacts 
65.  Beneficiaries. About 400,500 people in the subproject areas will benefit from increased 
agricultural income and more jobs. Many of them will benefit from natural disaster risk reduction 
and improved water supply for domestic use.

17
 
66.  Poverty Reduction. About 38% of the beneficiary households of the subprojects are 
below the poverty line of $0.33 per person per day,48 well above the national average of 24%. 
Farm benefits (after financing) with the Project would be D8 million–D15 million for a farm of 1 
ha,  compared  with  D3  million–D9  million  without  the  project.  Generally,  farm  benefits  are 
expected to double and lift at least 6,000 households above the poverty line. The social analysis 
showed that the burden of poverty in the project area is disproportionately borne by women. 
Female-headed households constitute on average 25% of all households in the project area. 
They are particularly vulnerable to poverty on account of their limited access to land, adult labor, 
credit, capital, and technology. Fewer female-headed than male-headed households derive their 
main income from agriculture and forestry activities and a much higher proportion derive their 
main income from wage labor. A GAP will be implemented to help counter these imbalances. A 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10. 
 
67.  Gender and Development. The GAP will ensure that female farmers, female-headed 
households, and women of ethnic minority communities are targeted for (i) capacity building for 
effective participation in planning and decision making, (ii) representation in WUGs/WUAs, and 
(iii) health education focused on managing risks of HIV/AIDS. Training of female farmers by 
VWU staff members will cover leadership and decision making, participatory water resources 
planning, and business management of organizations. Staff members of DARD and the IMCs 
will join gender sensitization programs to build their capacity and skills to deliver services 
effectively to female farmers. The PPMU will ensure that the Project’s agricultural extension and 
training  programs  will  have  not  less  than  40%  female  trainees.  All  WUGs/WUAs  to  be 
developed under the Project will have female membership of not less than 40%. The Project will 
support HIV/AIDS-related awareness raising to counter the risk of HIV/AIDS among male and 
female  migrant  workers  and  reduce  risks  of  infection  among  local  populations  through  in-
migration of construction workers. The program will target high-risk population groups, including 
contractors, construction workers, migrants. 
 
68.  Disadvantaged Groups and Ethnic Minorities. In four subproject areas, the ethnic 
minority population is small (less than 5%) and inter-mixed with Kinh and, in accordance with 
ADB's  policy  on  indigenous  peoples,49  the  Project  should  not  make  distinctions  based  on 
ethnicity. The Project will identify and assist all poor and vulnerable households regardless of 
ethnicity. In the Thach Thanh scheme (Thanh Hoa Province) the Muong represent 58% of the 
population but they are totally integrated with the Kinh, having adopted Kinh style of dress, 
language, farming methods, and social systems. They no longer maintain any traditions or 
customs  that  reflect  a  uniqueness  or  potential  vulnerability  of  culture.  For  the  Tra  Cau 
subproject (Quang Ngai Province) where a commune of 100% Hre people will lose land, an 
EMDP has been prepared (Appendix 5). 
 
B.  Environmental Impacts 
69.  The  Project  is  classified  as  environmental  category  B.  It  will  improve  agricultural 
production and water supply for domestic use and render the subproject areas less vulnerable 
to natural disasters. The Project will change land use irreversibly in scattered small areas, but 
the environmental impacts will be minor because changes in cropped and forested areas will be 
small. The Project will have limited environmental impacts during construction and operation.

C.  Financial and Economic Benefits 
70.  Quantified  Benefits.  The  main  project  benefits  are  from  incremental  output  of 
agricultural production, deriving from (i) higher cropping intensities, especially in areas under 
rain-fed cultivation; (ii) higher yields because of reliable and full irrigation water supply; and (iii) 
incremental output from shrimp and fish farming. The main crops cultivated in the subproject 
areas are rice, sugarcane, groundnut, and maize. The subprojects would increase the cultivated 
area from 52,432 ha without the Project to 57,755 ha with the Project. Aquaculture development 
takes place in Thuong My Trung with over 3,000 ha, based on fish raising in rice fields during 
the summer and autumn; in Tra Cau with 450 ha of shrimp raising in the winter and spring and 
300 ha in the summer and autumn seasons, in La Tinh with 300 ha of shrimp raising in the 
winter and spring and in the summer and autumn, and in south Thach Han with 200 ha of 
shrimp farming.  
 
71.  Nonquantified  Benefits.  The  Project  will  significantly  change  the  way  irrigation 
schemes are managed in the subprojects, giving much greater autonomy to IMCs and water 
user  groups,  reducing  transaction  costs  at  all  levels  of  their  operations,  and  helping  the 
Government phase out subsidies for O&M in the benefiting schemes. Roads to be constructed 
under the Project will provide better rural transportation and access to markets. Increased 
agricultural  production  will  contribute  to  the  agricultural  processing  industry  in  the  areas, 
especially in sugar factories. Increased incomes will be reflected in increased trade in nonfarm 
goods  and  services.  The  Project  will  reduce  poverty  in  some  remote  areas  with  a  high 
proportion of ethnic minority groups.  
 
72.  Economic Evaluation. The estimated Project economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is 
15% including institutional strengthening inputs. All subprojects are economically viable with 
EIRRs of 14–17%. Sensitivity analyses show that the economic feasibility of the subprojects is 
sensitive to (i) the success of aquaculture development, especially in the Thuong My Trung, Tra 
Cau, and La Tinh subprojects; and (ii) the timing of agricultural development, which is strongly 
related  to  completion  of  tertiary  canals  and  related  on-farm  development.  The  economic 
feasibility of the subprojects is less sensitive to changes in investment cost. The financial and 
economic evaluation is in Appendix 11. 
 
D.  Risks 
73.  The main risks arise from delays in realizing benefits—the Project’s economic viability is 
sensitive to this. Possible causes of delay are slowness in recruiting consultants and appointing 
appropriate central and provincial project management staff, resistance of vested interests to 
changes in organizational structure of service providers (IMCs and agricultural cooperatives), 
cumbersome administrative processes related to contract awards, and insensitive handling of 
resettlement. Resettlement and compensation of people affected by construction are on the 
critical path because the award of civil works contracts is conditional upon their prior completion. 
Project  consultants  will  help  the  provincial  authorities  complete  resettlement  on  schedule.

MARD has experience in, and a good understanding of Government and ADB requirements for

74.  Slow  farmer  adoption  of  irrigated  agricultural  production  systems  could  delay  the 
benefits. The economic analysis assumes that the whole target command area will be irrigated 
by the completion of each subproject or shortly after, and that cropping systems will have been 
adapted in the third year after completion. Three factors are expected to minimize these risks. 
First, farmers usually respond quickly if they have access to water, and if special attention is 
given  to  agricultural  extension  and  other  support  services.  Second,  experience  in  and 
knowledge of irrigated agriculture are widespread because a large part of the subproject areas 
is  being  irrigated.  Third,  beneficiary  participation  specifically  supported  by  the  Project  will 
increase  farmers’  awareness  of  the  benefits  of  restructuring  IMCs  and  the  concomitant 
conceding of powers to WUGs/WUAs, and will have involved farmers closely in the planning 
and implementation (often as contracted labor) of on-farm development. Agriculture extension 
services will support rapid uptake by disseminating information and demonstrating improved 
techniques. With this amount of support, a high level of participation should be assured. 
 
75.  Although MARD and the provincial agencies are experienced in implementing physical 
works, there are less so in the participatory and integrated approach needed for this Project. 
The strong support of MARD (through DWR), Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, 
Ministry of Finance, and Ministry of Planning and Investment at central level, and of PPC, DPI, 
DARD, and DoNRE at the provincial level will be critical to achieving the desired institutional 
changes. These changes will require shifts in strategies, regulations, and guidelines relating to 
irrigation service delivery. Overcoming these risks will be the Project’s most important task.

A.  Institutional Context 
1.  National Level Agencies 
1.  The Law on Water Resources, which became effective in 1999, assigns the Ministry of 
Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD)1 as the lead agency to implement and manage 
water resources projects, mainly irrigation and drainage, flood protection, rural water supply and 
sanitation,  typhoon  protection  measures,  and  most  major  hydraulic  structures.  MARD  also 
manages some hydropower schemes2 whose primary purpose is flood protection, and some 
national parks and conservation sites. Its Department of Water Resources (DWR) is responsible 
for  preparing  development  plans  for  rural  water  supply  and  sanitation  and  irrigation  and 
drainage schemes, and for overseeing rural water use.  
 
2.  In 2002, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MoNRE) was created and 
given  responsibility  for  state  management  of  natural  resources  and  the  environment.  This 
effectively separated state water management functions from public water service delivery, both 
of which functions had previously been held by MARD. The process of rationalizing the roles 
and  functions  of  the  many  agencies  involved  in  water  management,  and  of  establishing 
principles, guidelines, and accompanying regulatory systems for implementing integrated water 
resources management (IWRM), is underway.3 MoNRE has been charged with preparing the 
national water resources strategy (NWRS) for consideration of Cabinet by end-2005.4 MARD 
and MoNRE are both finalizing their 5-year plans for 2006–2010. 
 
3.  The Ministries of Planning and Investment, Finance, Construction, Industry, Fisheries, 
Health, and Transport, among others, play a role in water resources management and related 
issues. The Law on Water Resources defines the role of the National Water Resource Council 
(NWRC)5 to advise the Government on water resource  management, and related national 
strategies and action plans. It also provides for the establishment of river basin organizations as 
the appropriate institutions to manage water resources.

resources and supervising expenditures.6

14.  Farmers  have  direct  representation  in  agricultural  cooperatives  which  provide  such

15.  Two major constraints on water resource management limit Viet Nam’s ability to meet its 
rural  development  targets:  (i)  an  institutional  setting  that  encourages  service  providers’ 
dependence on government grants for O&M, and (ii) inefficient allocation of financial and other 
resources.

centrally defined rules and regulations.21 At the provincial level, the PPC has some leeway,

18.  IMC Institutional Analysis. A detailed analysis of the project area IMCs was made 
during the project preparatory TA. The analysis aimed to determine the IMCs’ strengths in terms 
of external22 and internal23 factors. In terms of their cultural (or external) environment, none of 
the IMCs is modern, most are either traditional or intermediate. Critically, all the IMCs have low 
scores for cost-efficiency, effectiveness, autonomy, and accountability, and are therefore at risk 
of failure. A simple measure of this can be seen by the fact that IMCs are only completing 20–
30% of the required maintenance even though they receive state subsidies in addition to user 
fees. IMCs in the project area are characterized as traditional, strongly risk-averse institutions 
with centralized leadership styles that limit participation of lower-level stakeholders in decision 
making.  
 
19.  IMC Performance. Water user fees in Viet Nam are high by international standards.24 
Hence,  the  failure  of  IMCs  to  meet  water  delivery  targets  or  to  undertake  maintenance 
throughout the command area is not due to a shortage of income. Other factors include the 
following: (i) water delivery is often unrelated to the cropping patterns of the areas served;25 (ii) 
many farmers are reluctant to pay user fees when water is not delivered in adequate quantities 
or at the correct time,26 or when farmers located further upstream are seen to have preferential 
access to water;27 (iii) IMCs use the income generated from user fees to meet recurrent costs 
and sometimes also as a source of general revenue (controlled by the PPC) for new works and 
scheme extensions;28 (iv) fees collected by the agricultural cooperatives are not always passed 
to the IMCs as they should be, and the cooperatives themselves sometimes divert revenue from 
fees to other uses;29 (v) some farmers use water without paying (non-revenue water to the 
IMC);30 (vi) the ceiling for fees in any year is set by the PPC and is more closely related to 
recurrent costs of IMC staff and operations than to O&M needs, thus encouraging the belief that 
maintenance of the schemes is a state responsibility.

D.  Government Measures to Improve Irrigation Performance 
23.  A key feature of water resource management is that many sectors have a stake in 
achieving greater efficiency or are highly susceptible to loss of access to water of adequate 
quantity and quality. In the agriculture sector, the full potential of irrigation schemes cannot be 
realized so long as water is inequitably distributed, large parts of the command areas are not 
served, or valuable water conveyance infrastructure is allowed to deteriorate. Irrigation currently 
consumes a disproportionately large part of Viet Nam’s available fresh water supply in lakes, 
rivers, wetlands, and groundwater reserves. In the face of increasing competition from higher 
value-added users, irrigation will have to become more efficient.  
 
24.  The Government is pursuing a new policy to improve the performance of irrigation and 
drainage schemes, and has realigned its strategy for water service delivery toward a more 
decentralized and participatory approach. The strategy relies on giving greater autonomy to 
service  providers  while  also  encouraging,  in  a  mutually  beneficial  partnership,  the  active 
participation of water users to relieve service providers’ O&M costs.

SUMMARY ETHNIC MINORITY DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND FRAMEWORK 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Ethnic minorities are among the poorest and least educated in Viet Nam. Although they 
represent only 14% of the population, they make up 29% of Viet Nam’s poor. The incidence of 
poverty  among  ethnic  minorities  is  declining  slowly,  from  86%  in  1993  to  69%  in  2002, 
compared with 54% to 23% for the majority Kinh. Viet Nam’s housing and living standards 
survey (2000)1 shows that the gap in living standards between Kinh and ethnic minorities has 
grown. In 12 of the 13 poorest provinces (those where more than 60% of the population are 
below the poverty line) ethnic minorities represent at least half the population. Expenditure per 
capita  among  ethnic  minority  households  is  13%  lower  than  for  Kinh  households.  The 
educational attainment of household heads and spouses is lower, too, and endowments in 
terms of housing and other assets are below average as well.  
 
2.  Ethnic minorities suffer from several interrelated causes of poverty such as geographic, 
social, and intellectual isolation; inadequate productive resources caused by lack of labor, land, 
capital, or skills; excessive health risks brought on by food inadequacy caused by poor crop 
productivity, disease, and unwanted births, among other factors; inadequate participation in 
planning  and  implementation  of  the  Government’s  relevant  programs;  and  environmental 
degradation.2 The compounded effect of these characteristics is such that minority households 
are substantially poorer than the Kinh, although it is important to note in terms of focusing 
government interventions that not all ethnic minority groups are equally disadvantaged.3  
 
B.  Government Policy Towards Ethnic Minorities  
3.  Viet Nam’s 1992 Constitution recognizes ethnic minorities as vulnerable groups and 
supports the provision of special assistance to bring development benefits to them. A ministerial 
level agency was created in 1959 to address ethnic minority development. It was supplanted in 
1994  by  the  Committee  for  Ethnic  Minorities  and  Mountainous  Areas  (CEMMA)  which 
coordinates and monitors ethnic minority development activities.  
 
4.  The Government aims to integrate ethnic minority groups into Vietnamese society and 
promote their greater participation in mainstream economic life by addressing inequities of both 
development  and  infrastructure  provision,  particularly  in  remote  and  mountainous  areas. 
Investments in specific projects are underpinned by country-wide poverty reduction programs 
that provide direct assistance to poor households and communes. The Hunger Eradication and 
Poverty Reduction (HEPR) and Program 135, both initiated in 1998, cover a range of benefits 
from  exemption  of  fees  and  taxes  (under  HEPR)  to  the  provision  of  grants  for  small 
infrastructure (under Program 135). Most of these initiatives come under CEMMA.

B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The poverty classification of the Project is targeted intervention. The Project comprises a number of elements that will 
have direct benefits for the poor: 
 
A social and poverty assessment was carried out for each of the subprojects in compliance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Bank Operations (1993). It included an assessment of the incidence of poverty 
which revealed the nature and perceptions of its causes: (i) lack of access to functioning irrigation and drainage, (ii)

low interest credit, (vi) surplus labor within the households and chronic unemployment or underemployment 
especially among the young, (vii) gender-related factors, and (viii) poor health, especially caused by waterborne 
diseases and malaria. 
 
The social analysis identified specific groups within the population who are particularly vulnerable and disadvantaged 
and unable to benefit fully from project interventions without some social preparation. There are significant numbers 
of poor landless households, many of them headed by women, and a high percentage of children living in poor 
households, many of whom have health problems related to Agent Orange. It also identified pockets of large 
numbers of pensioners and disability support recipients, as well as some ethnic minorities.

ranges from 35% in the Quang Ngai project area to 63% in Thanh Hoa. Improvements in irrigation and agricultural

vulnerable and thereby enhance the poverty reduction impact.

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC EVALUATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Financial and economic analyses were undertaken to evaluate the sustainability of each 
subproject and the Project as a whole. The financial analysis examined the sustainability of the 
proposed  irrigation  from  the  farmers’  point  of  view;  economic  analysis  determined  the 
incremental benefits, including increased primary sector production, domestic water supply, and 
flood  protection.  The  economic  analysis  was  disaggregated  to  demonstrate  the  returns  to 
investment from (i) irrigation infrastructure improvements and (ii) institutional strengthening of 
irrigation  service  providers—irrigation  management  companies  (IMCs).  The  institutional 
strengthening addresses risks associated with inadequate operation and maintenance (O&M) of 
infrastructure. While the institutional strengthening is assessed against the project impacts, 
significant positive externalities will be generated from the impact of these reforms on the full 
command areas of irrigation schemes under the IMC’s control.  
 
B.  Major Assumptions 
2.  The Project has an implementation period of 6 years and an assumed economic life of 
30 years with no residual value. For the analysis the interbank exchange rate of D15,800 per 
dollar at the time of the appraisal has been used. A discount rate of 12% has been used to 
ascertain the net present value (NPV) and also as the hurdle rate for the economic internal rate 
of return (EIRR). 
 
3.  Financial costs and benefits are estimated in constant mid-2003 terms. Technical and 
financial coefficients are based on the findings of the field surveys during the feasibility study in 
2004, and were adjusted for the economic analysis to 2005 terms during loan appraisal. The 
analysis uses a world price numeraire, where economic prices for traded outputs and inputs are 
based on the World Bank commodity price projections. Prices for rice paddy, maize, shrimp, 
and phosphatic and potassic fertilizers are estimated at import parity (Supplementary Appendix 
E). All other inputs and outputs have been valued at competitive market prices, after adjusting 
for taxes, duties, and an implicit overvaluation of the exchange rate. Electricity used in pumping 
has been valuated at its long-run marginal cost of supply. A conversion factor of 0.9 has been 
used to express civil works in efficiency terms. In the case of unskilled labor, a shadow wage 
rate factor of 0.6 has been used to express the wages in terms of opportunity costs. For semi-
skilled labor a shadow wage rate factor of 0.7 has been used. Domestic prices of non-traded 
goods and services have been converted to their economic equivalent by multiplying their 
financial prices by a standard conversion factor of 0.9. 
 
4.  Crop models were prepared using the FARMOD software for a range of farm sizes 
within each of the schemes, based on expected yield, cropping intensity, and cropping patterns. 
For the financial analysis, only hired labor has been costed while for the economic analysis both 
family and hired labor have been included (Supplementary Appendix E).

F.  Institutional Analysis 
20.  Each irrigation scheme is managed through an IMC under the control of provincial 
authorities. IMCs are state-owned enterprises that face significant limitations in their autonomy 
and role. The national and provincial regulations under which the IMCs work leave little freedom 
for local decision making. The IMCs are financed through water-use fees whose levels are 
determined by provincial authorities. The revenue provides sufficient revenue for the fixed and 
variable costs of the organizations but not for the full O&M costs of the irrigation schemes which 
continue to degrade. The IMCs have little knowledge of the water users and their needs, or of 
the irrigation schemes they serve—all of which limits their ability to prioritize the allocation and 
use  of  water  and  to  plan  maintenance  programs.  During  the  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance,  their  management  capacity  was  assessed  as  weak,  with  limited  capacity  and 
opportunity for strategic decision making.  
 
21.  The financial viability of IMCs is “at risk” because of their (i) lack of strategic focus, (ii) 
continued focus on engineering works and skills that are no longer required, (iii) inability to 
deliver reliable and timely water (which reduces water fee collection rates), (iv) inappropriate 
water fees, (v) non-involvement of water users in the management and operation of irrigation 
schemes, and (vi) unclear ownership of irrigation assets. Most IMCs operate with financial 
deficits,  which  are  financed  through  national  and  provincial  subsidies.  Financial  resources 
constrain O&M of schemes.  
 
22.  For Thanh Hoa, a 50% increase in water revenue is needed to break even on current 
cost structures. To additionally finance the predicted incremental increase in O&M costs, a 
100% increase in water fees is needed. The Project will provide significant support to develop 
business plans that will move the IMCs toward financial autonomy. The release of project funds 
for  civil  works  in  the  subprojects  will  be  conditional  upon  the  IMCs’  providing  acceptable 
business plans. This will mitigate the risk of increased deficits among the IMCs. 
 
G.  Risk 
23.  The economic analysis assumes that the whole of the net command area is converted to 
irrigated production phased in over 3 years following construction. The major risk is the ability of 
the DARDs to achieve the construction schedule and of the IMCs to provide water in a timely 
and reliable manner. The risks have been addressed through the linking of construction to the 
development of business plans and through the use of a extended construction schedule based 
on 0%, 10%, 25% 35%, 20%, 10% by project year. The level of water-user support provided for 
on-farm  works  and  the  establishment  of  WUGs/WUAs  will  ensure  that  the  beneficiaries 
participate in the design and implementation of tertiary irrigation development early on. This 
support will increase awareness of the potential benefits of the subproject and help create a 
partnership of WUGs and IMCs to strengthen O&M of the infrastructure provided. Training for 
improved  irrigation  management  will  be  provided.  In  addition,  beneficiaries  will  avail  of
